mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Ginseng has been central to Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years. Wild mountain ginseng (particularly from Changbai Mountain) commands astronomical prices. The plant appears in countless folk tales of ginseng spirits, hunters' adventures, and cultivation stories. It remains a symbol of health, vitality, and natural wisdom.

textReferences.context: Lists ginseng as a superior herb that prolongs life and strengthens spirit
Li Shizhen's comprehensive description of ginseng's properties and uses
Ginseng as ingredient in external and internal alchemy

rituals.description: Traditional harvesters performed rituals before digging wild ginseng, believing the plant's spirit must be appeased
rituals.name: Ginseng Harvest Ritual

rituals.description: Daoist alchemists used ancient ginseng as a key ingredient in elixirs of immortality
rituals.name: Immortality Elixir
Qi Cultivation
rituals.description: Cultivators consume ginseng to strengthen their qi and accelerate spiritual development

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Ginseng embodies the union of heaven and earth energies, extracting essence from soil (yin) and air (yang) over decades or centuries. Its human-like form represents the microcosm-macrocosm principle - as above, so below. The longer it grows, the more it accumulates the subtle energies of the cosmos, making it a bridge between mortal and immortal realms.
mythologyContexts.usage: Used in traditional medicine, Daoist alchemy, immortality elixirs, and cultivation practices. Ancient ginseng roots are sought by cultivators and immortals for their concentrated life essence

shortDescription: Sacred medicinal root believed to contain concentrated qi and promote longevity

etymology.components: ‰∫∫ (person, human) + ÂèÉ (join, penetrate) - named for human-shaped root

originPoint.description: Wild ginseng grows in mountain forests; particularly valued from Changbai Mountains region

temporal.culturalContext: Traditional Chinese Medicine; qi cultivation; longevity practices; imperial tribute system

firstAttestation.description: Shennong Ben Cao Jing (Divine Farmer's Materia Medica) classifies ginseng as superior herb for longevity

longDescription: Ginseng (‰∫∫ÂèÉ, r√©nshƒìn, literally 'man-root') is a sacred medicinal herb central to Chinese medicine and Daoist alchemy. The root, which often resembles a human figure, is believed to contain concentrated life energy (qi) and possess extraordinary healing and rejuvenating properties. Wild ginseng, especially specimens aged hundreds of years, is considered supremely valuable and is believed to grant longevity, vitality, and spiritual power. In mythology, ginseng spirits can take human form and possess consciousness.

worshipPractices: Used in traditional medicine, Daoist alchemy, immortality elixirs, and cultivation practices. Ancient ginseng roots are sought by cultivators and immortals for their concentrated life essence

The plant appears in countless folk tales of ginseng spirits, hunters' adventures, and cultivation stories. It remains a symbol of health, vitality, and natural wisdom.
